reply_context.text: There's a social mechanism here. Medical researchers are not statisticians. reply_context.text: My hand is moving away from the stove before my brain has even received the signal to evoke a pain sensation. This isn't problematic under a systems perspective of an organism: it just means that certain simple decision processes are delegated down. Low level processes are still part of the organism

posts.text: My hand is moving away from the stove before my brain has even received the signal to evoke a pain sensation. This isn't problematic under a systems perspective of an organism: it just means that certain simple decision processes are delegated down. Low level processes are still part of the organism

reply_context.text: the benefit of going more "systems" with it is that it accounts for lower level reflexes. If I put my hand on a stove and you ask me why I pulled it away, I'd say "because it hurt and I wanted to stop the pain," but the truth is that particular reflex is governed by spinal nerves.

posts.text: the benefit of going more "systems" with it is that it accounts for lower level reflexes. If I put my hand on a stove and you ask me why I pulled it away, I'd say "because it hurt and I wanted to stop the pain," but the truth is that particular reflex is governed by spinal nerves.

reply_context.text: I‚Äôm partial to this shape of argument, though maybe my version would benefit from more systems thinking

posts.text: i know it's gauche to mention him, but this reminds me of minsky's "society of mind"

reply_context.text: Manuel DeLanda develops similar line of argument in his _Materialist Phenomenology_ when he talks about a hierarchy of more or less capable agents making up a system as a way of avoiding the homunculus fallacy (or Dennett‚Äôs Cartesian Theater).

posts.text: a simple organismic response to this is to point out the fundamental attribution error. I'm not even fully aware of how my own subsystems produce my decision making process, but that doesn't mean those decisions aren't mine. I am still the joint system, including the opaque, rule-based parts.

reply_context.text: By the way, Searle‚Äôs objection to the system reply (that the person inside the room can memorize the rulebook, leave the room, and then embody all the joint system properties without gaining any understanding) does not survive Hayekian complexity-based critique.

posts.text: yeah the systems response to the chinese room is that it is perfectly coherent to describe the complete system behind the interface (person + rule book) as a competent chinese speaker.

reply_context.text: I figured the idea with the chinese room is that it's not the individuals that communicate but the system that includes the participants as parts

posts.text: tldr: heterogenous priorities and information asymmetry at one level of organization necessitates the existence of faculties at higher levels of organization that can negotiate conflicts and coordinate planning.
